instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No start
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with startup problem. Fan spins but no start. 

Measure 20v with 0.2amp

Seems to have all lines with correct value accept <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> 0V

Is there anything to do with this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No start
threads.message: Do you get CPU core voltage for sure (L7211/21/31)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No start
threads.message: <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> dont send out <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> but all rails to it are there. costumer wanted it back fast so didnt want too dig any further last week when I got it, already picked up again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No start
threads.message: PCH requires some power goods signals first; did you check them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No start
threads.message: yes i did all of them was present
